clean_content:
Definition / general

* Malignant exocrine neoplasm of the pancreas composed of cells with morphological resemblance to acinar cells and with immunohistochemistry positive for acinar markers

Essential features

* Epithelial neoplasm showing acinar differentiation* Immunohistochemical positivity for BCL10 and trypsin ([Virchows Arch 2009;454:133](19066953), [Cancer Cytopathol 2013;121:459](23408736), [Pathologica 2020;112:210](33179623))

Terminology

* Main category: acinar cell carcinoma* Subtypes: acinar cell cystoadenocarcinoma, mixed acinar neuroendocrine carcinoma, mixed acinar ductal adenocarcinoma

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [8550/3](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=76) - acinar cell carcinoma* ICD-11: [2C10.0 & XH3PG9](https://icd.who.int/browse11/l-m/en#/http%3a%2f%2fid.who.int%2ficd%2fentity%2f1663659989?data=%7B%22dataType%22%3A%22pc%22%2C%22postcoordinationCodeSet%22%3A%7B%22stemId%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Fid.who.int%2Ficd%2Fentity%2F1663659989%22%2C%22axisToValueIds%22%3A%7B%22histopathology%22%3A%5B%7B%22stemId%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Fid.who.int%2Ficd%2Fentity%2F1322159869%22%7D%5D%7D%7D%7D) - adenocarcinoma of the pancreas & acinar cell carcinoma

Epidemiology

* M:F = 2.1:1 ([Semin Diagn Pathol 2016;33:307](27320062), [Am J Surg Pathol 2012;36:1782](23026929))* Average age: 60 years ([Semin Diagn Pathol 2016;33:307](27320062))* 1 - 2% of all pancreatic neoplasms in adults and 15% in children ([Semin Diagn Pathol 2016;33:307](27320062))

Sites

* Head of the pancreas is the most common site ([Semin Diagn Pathol 2016;33:307](27320062))

Pathophysiology

* Accumulation of genetic alteration, including chromosomal instability and frequent allelic copy number variation

Etiology

* Tobacco smoking, defective DNA repair; presence of chromosomal instability and frequent allelic copy number variation ([Nat Commun 2017;8:1323](29109526))* Most cases are sporadic but a minority (< 10%) are associated with Lynch syndrome, familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome and Carney complex

Clinical features

* Presenting symptoms include abdominal or back pain, weight loss, nausea, vomiting; jaundice is more rarely observed than in ductal adenocarcinoma ([Am J Surg Pathol 1992;16:815](1384374))* In the case of extensive metastatic disease, patients may show symptoms related to lipase hypersecretion, including subcutaneous fat necrosis ([Front Med (Lausanne) 2015;2:41](26137463))

Diagnosis

* CT scan and MRI are the preferred imaging modality ([J Belg Soc Radiol 2019;103:43](31276097))* Diagnosis is by biopsy or surgical resection

Laboratory

* Rarely, patients can show increased levels of AFP, especially young patients ([Hum Pathol 2000;31:938](10987254))* Patients with metastatic disease can show elevated levels of serum lipase ([World J Clin Cases 2020;8:5304](33269263))

Radiology description

* Typical CT and MRI features of pancreatic acinar cell carcinoma: relatively large mass with a well defined margin, exophytic growth and heterogeneous enhancement ([J Belg Soc Radiol 2019;103:43](31276097))

Prognostic factors

* The prognosis is poor, with an average survival time of about 19 months ([Semin Diagn Pathol 2016;33:307](27320062))* To date, the TNM stage can be considered the only significant prognostic moderator ([Am J Surg Pathol 2012;36:1782](23026929))* Tumors with intraductal growth display a better prognosis than conventional acinar cell carcinomas ([Am J Surg Pathol 2007;31:363](17325477))

Case reports

* 41 and 77 year old men presenting with acinar cell carcinoma extensively involving the pancreas ([Medicine (Baltimore) 2017;96:e7904](28930825))* 52 year old man with acinar cell carcinoma of the pancreas harboring *BRCA2* germline mutation ([Cancer Biol Ther 2019;20:949](31002019))* 69 year old man with acinar cell carcinoma of the pancreas mixed with ductal adenocarcinoma ([World J Surg Oncol 2020;18:238](32891173))* 71 year old man with acinar cell carcinoma of the pancreas, with extension into the main pancreatic duct ([Surg Case Rep 2021;7:90](33847839))* 81 year old man with acinar cell carcinoma of the pancreas harboring *NTRK* fusion gene, with exceptional response to molecularly based target therapy ([J Natl Compr Canc Netw 2021;19:10](33406492))

Treatment

* Surgical resection if possible, gemcitabine based chemotherapy / radiofrequency ablation, molecularly based target therapy in the case of actionable alterations ([World J Clin Cases 2020;8:1241](32337198))

Gross description

* Well circumscribed mass, at least partially encapsulated, solid and large, with fleshy consistency

Gross images

AFIP images  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/images/pancreas/4_090.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/images/pancreas/4_090.jpg)

Cut surface displays large nodules

Frozen section description

* Hypercellular neoplasm with acinar resembling cells

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Unlike conventional [ductal adenocarcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html), this tumor is highly cellular and with scant fibrous stroma* Cells show moderate amounts of granular eosinophilic cytoplasm containing PAS positive diastase resistant zymogen granules* Nuclei are uniform with a typically present, single and prominent nucleolus ([Semin Diagn Pathol 2016;33:307](27320062))* Perineural invasion and vascular invasion are very common* Can have different architectures and growth patterns, including cystic, acinar, glandular and intraductal* Nonneuroendocrine component of mixed neuroendocrine nonneuroendocrine neoplasms (MiNEN) in the pancreas can be represented by acinar cell carcinoma; MiNEN diagnosis should be based on both morphology and immunohistochemistry

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Claudio Luchini, M.D., Ph.D.

Typical histology

[![Intraductal growth](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini2.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini2.jpg)

[![Cell detail](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini3.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini3.jpg)

Cell detail

[![Association with neuroendocrine tumors](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini6.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini6.jpg)
 
[![Association with neuroendocrine tumors](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini7.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini7.jpg)

Association with neuroendocrine tumors

  

[![BCL10 expression pattern](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini4.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini4.jpg)

BCL10 expression pattern

[![Trypsin expression pattern](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini5.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchini5.jpg)

Trypsin expression pattern

Cytology description

* Hypercellular / moderately cellular neoplasm, monomorphic nuclei with prominent nucleoli ([Diagn Cytopathol 2017;45:247](27860444))

Cytology images

Contributed by Claudio Luchini, M.D., Ph.D.  

[![Cytological aspects](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchiniCyto01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasacinarLuchiniCyto01.jpg)

Cytological aspects

Positive stains

* [Keratins](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsckgeneral.html) (particularly [CK7](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck7.html) and [CK8](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck8.html) / [CK18](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck18.html) / [CK19](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck19.html)), [BCL10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbcl10.html) (particularly the clone 331.3) and [trypsin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainstrypsin.html) ([Virchows Arch 2009;454:133](19066953), [Cancer Cytopathol 2013;121:459](23408736), [Pathologica 2020;112:210](33179623))* Nuclear expression of [beta catenin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbetacatenin.html) and [CD200](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd200.html) expression is found in about 10% of cases ([Am J Surg Pathol 2012;36:1782](23026929), [Virchows Arch 2019;474:105](30132130))

Negative stains

* Neoplastic cells are negative for [chromogranin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainschromogranin.html) and [synaptophysin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssynaptophysin.html) (rarely, scattered positive cells may be present)

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* Most common molecular alterations of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (e.g. *KRAS* and *SMAD4* mutations) are usually absent* Recurrent presence of *BRAF*, *RAF1* and *RET* rearrangements ([Cancer Discov 2014;4:1398](25266736), [Mod Pathol 2020;33:1811](32358589), [Mod Pathol 2020;33:657](31558784))* Wnt pathway alterations with *APC / CTNNB1* mutations can be present in a subset of cases

Sample pathology report

* Distal stomach, duodenum and pancreatic head, pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple resection):
  + Acinar cell carcinoma of the pancreas, 2.2 cm+ Carcinoma involves distal bile duct+ All margins negative for carcinoma+ Positive for lymphovascular invasion and perineural invasion+ Metastatic carcinoma involving 1 of 27 lymph nodes+ Portion of benign stomach and duodenum with no significant pathologic change

Differential diagnosis

* [Neuroendocrine neoplasms](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreaspen.html):
  + [BCL10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbcl10.html) negative, [chromogranin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainschromogranin.html) and [synaptophysin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssynaptophysin.html) positive+ Salt and pepper chromatin+ No evident nucleoli* [Pancreatoblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreaspancreatoblastoma.html):
    + Pancreatic neoplasm with acinar differentiation: the presence of squamoid nests is diagnostic for pancreatoblastoma* [Intraductal tubulopapillary neoplasm (ITPN)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasitpn.html):
      + In cases with intraductal growth+ [BCL10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbcl10.html) negative and [MUC6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmuc2.html) positive

Additional references

* [WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board: Digestive System Tumours, 5th Edition, 2019](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283244990/pathologyoutl-20)
